description: From Middle English Jake (variant of “Jack”) or Jakke (variant of “Jacques” and “Jack”). Use as a place to urinate and defecate first attested in the form jacques. Compare terms such as US slang Cousin John and Quincy, used as euphemistic personifications the speaker was "visiting".

entries.meaning: plural of jake in its various senses.
A jakes.(now chiefly Ireland) A place to urinate and defecate: an outhouse or lavatory.
examples: And the treasures of the floor and walls went raw into the jakeses from my brush and dustpan: sludges, geodes, hair, dead insects and arachnidae, a rubber glove and tainted paper waste, a mouse's skull and tail, a set of used plasters,  […]

entries.meaning: third-person singular simple present indicative form of jake: to play a form of prank
